{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3555921,"name":null,"username":"swifteh30","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/d2c977/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T08:08:29.804Z","cooked":"

If swerve drive uses all the large terminals on the PDP, is there a way I could connect the motor for my superstructure to the smaller terminals instead?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-03-13T08:08:29.804Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":202,"readers_count":201,"score":45.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495426,"topic_slug":"limited-pdp","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74278,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/limited-pdp/495426/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3555922,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T08:12:48.211Z","cooked":"

Sure is!

You can use a 30A or 20A Snap-Action breaker and you’ll be all set. I think REV’s 40A will fit as well, but I haven’t checked that.

Depending on amperage needs, you may be able to shift swerve steering motors over to the “smaller” slots if you need something else in the 40A range (assuming the REV 40A units won’t fit in the smaller slots).

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-03-13T08:12:48.211Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":202,"readers_count":201,"score":40.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495426,"topic_slug":"limited-pdp","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/limited-pdp/495426/2","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3555962,"name":"Ari Meles-Braverman","username":"AriMB","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arimb/{size}/189989_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T10:57:05.090Z","cooked":"

REV 40A breakers and Snap Action AT2 40A breakers do fit in the PDP smaller ports, and are legal according to R619.

The REV breakers actually have a longer trip time than the Snap Action AT2 or MX5 (small or large) 40A breakers. So it may counterintuitively be better to put your higher-current motors on the smaller ports.

team 2056 (OP) is a great example of using the PDP1.0 - check out these photos from their tech binder thread:

Team 2056 OP Robotics - 2024 Technical Binder Release Technical Discussion
The CAN wires go into the first motor, back out to the encoder, back to the second motor in the module, and then to the next CAN device, the routing stays organized by incorporating zip tie mounts into the swerve cover. The CAN and Power wires go through a cut-out on the top swerve module cover and these get soldered directly to the CANcoder board. [PXL_20241025_150317286] [image] [image]

-FLS/FRS/BLS/BRS are Front/Back Left/Right swerve steering motors (in the smaller ports)
-FLD/FRD/BLD/BRD are Front/Back Left/Right swerve driving motors (in the larger ports)

I do also second the above that, with 40amp REV ATO breakers you can use any of the small ports for high power applications as well
